Award.AwardTitle: Development of a Designer Fluid for Phase Change Heat Transfer in Different Materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET 1336896
PI: Catton

The project goals are twofold; 1) yield an understanding of the chemistry of an inorganic aqueous solution that is sufficient to develop a ?designer fluid? for a particular heat transfer application and 2) establish the ability of such a designer fluid to enhance heat transfer in the phase change device (heat pipes, recuperators, and/or thermosiphons) within which it is to be used. The understanding of the chemistry, the first part of the project, will be quantified to establish the impact of the type and amount of the chemical constituents. A library of various applications and suggested chemical constituents will be developed. What is needed to passivate various materials, to relate the mixture constituents and their molality to passivation, hydrophilicity, surface deposition and microstructure will be established. The second part of the project is to quantify the capacity of a designer fluid to enhance heat transfer in the device in which it is to be used. A correlation between the deposition of material and construction of the micro-porous coatings to the chemistry, pH and temperature of the mix will be developed. The heat transfer will be related to the amount and type of constituents and their capacity to construct micro-porous coatings on a surface and to the hydrophilicity and capillarity of the surface microstucture. The impact of such a designer fluid on the effectiveness of various types of wicking will complete the project.

Water is one of natures best heat transfer fluids when phase change is involved because it has the highest heat of evaporation. Unfortunately water is also a good oxidizer and can lead to corrosion and, if a metal, hydrogen production that can seriously degrade the heat transfer performance. Presently, water can only be used with metals like copper. In this work, a novel, inorganic aqueous solution is developed for use with aluminum and other material heat pipes and thermosiphons that will improve the heat transfer performance by as much as a factor of two. The chemical reactions responsible for passivating the device material interior and preventing generation of non condensible gases (NCG) will be explained. Being able to use a phase change heat transfer fluid that has the equivalent or better heat transfer performance than water in a range of different materials will have a significant impact on many aspects of the power generation, process and electronics industries and our ability to harvest waste heat.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A unique group of designer fluids for use in wicked phase change devices like heat pipes or recuperators has been developed from the originally patented Inorganic Aqueous Solution (IAS) created and studied at UCLA. These fluids create microstructures on the surface of a wick in situ through chemical reactions and solubility forced deposits. This surface augmentation is inherently hydrophilic and has been shown to increase the performance and dry-out heat flux in a variety of wicks. To our knowledge, use of such a fluid is the first attempt at using a dilute IAS for performance enhancement in phase change heat transfer devices. This type of chemically reacting working fluid is particularly promising because of the cost and reliability associated with the inorganic constituents and coating respectively. The goal of the grant is to fully characterize the impact of altering the chemistry of the fluid in order to marry a custom fluid with a custom application.  This includes the impact of changing concentrations, pH values, and other parameters to adapt to specific materials and environments. The elements of this part of the work are the following: 

  1. Develop understanding of the impact of changing constituent concentrations based on chemsitry and thermodynamics,
  2. Develop a library of “recipes” for various applications so that tailored fluids can be suggested,
  3. Understand the required chemistry in order to passivate various surfaces,
  4. Relate the mixture constituents and their molarity to passivation, hydrophilicity and surface deposition and
  5. Heat Transfer Enhancement.

Heat pipes are a highly effective means of managing heat generated by electronics and other sources because they are able to transfer heat under near isothermal conditions across the device. Specific applications and implementations are covered extensively in existing literature.  In a heat pipe, the use of pure water in conjunction with aluminum is an incompatible combination which will generate hydrogen gas. Hydrogen is a non-condensable gas (NCG) and will build up in the condenser creating a large thermal resistance. This results in catastrophic decreases of the effective thermal performance and often leads quickly to outright failure. Ammonia heat pipes are often used in aluminum casings to avoid NCG generation, however, this has performance drawbacks and care must be taken to ensure only highly anhydrous ammonia is used.  The qualification of water-based fluids for use with aluminum will increase their performance while expanding the range of operating temperatures for aluminum heat pipes.

IAS is especially unique due to its ability to both passivate aluminum devices as well as increase the thermal performance of copper based devices. The results obtained cover the theoretical and experimental investigations of the fluid for aluminum and copper phase change heat transfer devices done under this research grant. The fluid’s chemical analysis and improvements and justifications for modifications to the fluid while providing insight into further chemical design and how the constituents can be optimized for different applications followed by focus on aluminum passivation are reported. Thermodynamic modeling of the chemical reactions involved with IAS and hydrogen generation suppression was developed and used to analyze previous experimental results in aluminum thermosiphons. The theory of discontinuous flow and its effect on passivation was tested experimentally as well.  

Thermal performance enhancement in copper devices was a major element of this study. A grooved flat heat pipe is used to obtain accurate performance results as well as useful visual observations of the nature and location of the fluids deposits. Theoretical flow and diffusion analysis is used to exp...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: A unique group of designer fluids for use in wicked phase change devices like heat pipes or recuperators has been developed from the originally patented Inorganic Aqueous Solution (IAS) created and studied at UCLA. These fluids create microstructures on the surface of a wick in situ through chemical reactions and solubility forced deposits. This surface augmentation is inherently hydrophilic and has been shown to increase the performance and dry-out heat flux in a variety of wicks. To our knowledge, use of such a fluid is the first attempt at using a dilute IAS for performance enhancement in phase change heat transfer devices. This type of chemically reacting working fluid is particularly promising because of the cost and reliability associated with the inorganic constituents and coating respectively. The goal of the grant is to fully characterize the impact of altering the chemistry of the fluid in order to marry a custom fluid with a custom application. This includes the impact of changing concentrations, pH values, and other parameters to adapt to specific materials and environments. The elements of this part of the work are the following: Develop understanding of the impact of changing constituent concentrations based on chemsitry and thermodynamics, Develop a library of "recipes" for various applications so that tailored fluids can be suggested, Understand the required chemistry in order to passivate various surfaces, Relate the mixture constituents and their molarity to passivation, hydrophilicity and surface deposition and Heat Transfer Enhancement. Heat pipes are a highly effective means of managing heat generated by electronics and other sources because they are able to transfer heat under near isothermal conditions across the device. Specific applications and implementations are covered extensively in existing literature. In a heat pipe, the use of pure water in conjunction with aluminum is an incompatible combination which will generate hydrogen gas. Hydrogen is a non-condensable gas (NCG) and will build up in the condenser creating a large thermal resistance. This results in catastrophic decreases of the effective thermal performance and often leads quickly to outright failure. Ammonia heat pipes are often used in aluminum casings to avoid NCG generation, however, this has performance drawbacks and care must be taken to ensure only highly anhydrous ammonia is used. The qualification of water-based fluids for use with aluminum will increase their performance while expanding the range of operating temperatures for aluminum heat pipes. IAS is especially unique due to its ability to both passivate aluminum devices as well as increase the thermal performance of copper based devices. The results obtained cover the theoretical and experimental investigations of the fluid for aluminum and copper phase change heat transfer devices done under this research grant. The fluidÆs chemical analysis and improvements and justifications for modifications to the fluid while providing insight into further chemical design and how the constituents can be optimized for different applications followed by focus on aluminum passivation are reported. Thermodynamic modeling of the chemical reactions involved with IAS and hydrogen generation suppression was developed and used to analyze previous experimental results in aluminum thermosiphons. The theory of discontinuous flow and its effect on passivation was tested experimentally as well. Thermal performance enhancement in copper devices was a major element of this study. A grooved flat heat pipe is used to obtain accurate performance results as well as useful visual observations of the nature and location of the fluids deposits. Theoretical flow and diffusion analysis is used to explain the fluidÆs behavior. Overall, the report provides extremely useful background, analysis, and experimental results for the further development of a working dessigner fluid. Last Modifie...
